Thomas Farr must not be confirmed to a lifetime appointment as a Federal Judge in North Carolina. It‚Äôs hard to believe President Trump nominated him, and it‚Äôs even harder to believe the Senate Republicans are considering it again.
Farr appealed to the United States Supreme Court which also rejected his arguments and affirmed the District Court‚Äôs ruling. http://www.scotusblog.com/case-files/cases/mccrory-v-harris/

The court held that ‚Äúrace predominated in both‚Äù congressional districts and that the 2011 redistricting ‚Äúaffected North Carolina citizens' fundamental right to vote, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.‚Äù https://www.leagle.com/decision/infdco20160208846

Farr argued that plaintiffs had ‚Äúfailed to demonstrate that race was the ‚Äòpredominant factor‚Äô used by the General Assembly in drawing‚Äù the two congressional districts. A U.S. District Court rejected Farr‚Äôs arguments.

In Harris v. McCrory, yet another challenge to NC‚Äôs 2011 redistricting plan, the plaintiffs alleged that the NC legislature violated the 14th Amendment when it used race as the predominant consideration with respect to two congressional districts redrawn after the 2010 census.

Although the NC Supreme Court agreed with Farr, the U.S. Supreme Court ultimately vacated the state court‚Äôs judgment. They remanded the decision in light of Harris v. McCrory/Cooper v. Harris. What did this decision say?

In his arguments, Farr dismissed the challenges as politically motivated and argued that NC had a compelling interest ‚Äúin preemptively factoring race into its redistricting process‚Äù to avoid liability under the Voting Rights Act.

In 2014, Farr represented NC in Dickson v. Rucho, a case in which both the legislative and the congressional plans in the state‚Äôs 2011 redistricting were challenged as impermissible racial gerrymanders.

In their rejection, the court held the districts unconstitutional, citing ‚Äúcopious statewide evidence‚Äù that ‚Äúrace was the predominant criterion in drawing all of the challenged districts.‚Äù The decision was later affirmed by the Supreme Court. https://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/legal-work/Covington_PerCuriamOpinion_06.05.17.pdf

In Covington v. NC, Farr argued that race was not the primary factor used in the redistricting. And even if it was, Farr argued the NC legislature‚Äôs use of race was reasonably necessary to comply with the Voting Rights Act. The trial court rejected this argument.

In 2016-17, Farr represented NC in Covington v. NC, a challenge to the state‚Äôs 2011 legislative redistricting alleging each of NC‚Äôs 19 state House districts & 9 state Senate districts constituted a racial gerrymander violating the Equal Protection Clause. https://www.brennancenter.org/legal-work/north-carolina-v-covington
